question: Starvation and Diabetes mellitus can lead to ketosis. Which of the following features are in or of ketosis in diabetes mellitus:
exp: =Diabetic situation is same like fasting or starvation i.e. catabolic situation in the body. =There is relative or absolute deficiency of insulin. =This leads to increased Glucagon, increased cAMP & increased Blood Glucose. Insulin dependent GLUT-4 is not working in Diabetes, so blood glucose cannot enter peripheral tissues. Plasma free fatty acid levels will be raised as catabolic enzyme - Hormone Sensitive Lipase (HSL) will be active in adipose tissues, which breaks down TGs into fatty acid & glycerol. Fatty acids travel to blood and liver, where beta oxidation of fatty acids takes place. In a chronic diabetes patient, plasma TG and VLDL will also be raised. Pathways which are activated in diabetes are : Beta oxidation of fatty acids Gluconeogenesis Ketone body synthesis Lipolysis of adipose tissues
opa: Increase in glucagon / insulin ratio, increased cAMP and increased blood glucose
opb: Decreased insulin, increased free fatty acid which is equivalent to blood glucose
opc: Decreased insulin, increased free fatty acid which is not equivalent to blood glucose
opd: Elevated insulin and free fatty acid, equivalent to blood glucose

question: In diabetics, the factor which is limiting for the synthesis of triglycerides in adipose tissue is:
exp: For making TGs, glycerol-3-P is joined with fatty acids. But there is only one enzyme in Adipose tissues for the synthesis of Glycerol-3-P and that is Glycerol-3-P Dehydrogenase which synthesize Glycerol-3-P from DHAP. This DHAP is derived from Glucose. So Glucose entry is must in Adipose tissues for TG synthesis. This occurs with the help of glucose channel - GLUT-4. In liver, there are two enzymes for TG synthesis : 1. Glycerol-3-P Dehydrogenase 2. Glycerol Kinase

question: A 15-year-old type I diabetic faints after injecting himself with insulin. He is administered Glucagon and rapidly recovers consciousness. Glucagon induces activity of:
exp: Glucagon (catabolic hormone) activates the Rate limiting enzyme of glycogenolysis (catabolic pathway) i.e. Glycogen phosphorylase. ADDITIONAL EDGE: Fig.: In fasting state, Glucagon hormone is released. Regulation of glycogen metabolism at the level of glycogen phosphorylase: cAMP activates phosphorylase kinase (by a cAMP-dependent protein kinase), which in turn activates glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium activates the calmodulin component of phosphorylase kinase directly, which in turn activates glycogen phosphorylase. 5' AMP acts allosterically to activate glycogen phosphorylase. Protein phosphatase-1 inactivates glycogen phosphorylase.

question: In diabetes and starvation, acidosis occur due to:
exp: In Diabetes and Starvation, Ketone bodies are formed in excess, leading to ketoacidosis. In Diabetes and during starvation, beta Oxidation of fatty acids occur in liver producing Acetyl CoA for the synthesizes of Ketone bodies as the main fuel which is primarily the source of energy for Brain, Hea, Skeletal muscles.

question: The activity of which of the following enzymes is increased in Diabetes Mellitus?
exp: Diabetic situation is same like fasting or starvation i.e. catabolic situation in the body. So, in Diabetes Mellitus, the activity of Catabolic enzymes is increased. Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase-I (CPT-I) is an enzyme of b-Oxidation which is a Catabolic pathway. Therefore, it is increased in Diabetes. Option b & c - Phosphoenol Pyruvate Carboxykinase (PEPCK) and Glucose -6-Phosphatase are enzymes of Gluconeogenesis which is a Catabolic pathway and hence increased in Diabetes. So, answer is all.
